author: Lyle LaBonte

review: Fire TV is good for games (for a set top streaming box) compared to Apple TV and Roku, but its key feature (voice search) is overrated.  It works well for Amazon content, but can't be used for other content.  Also, some of the apps are still sketchy regarding Fire TV compatibility, even those with native Android support.  For gaming, and speed of searching I would give this a 4 with a chance for 5 stars in the next iteration or two.  However, for searching I would go with either Apple TV or Roku.  For agnostic support, Roku for sure, for iTunes lovers then Apple TV.
author: Moondeep

author: Richard K. Enos

review: I am SO disappointed in this device.  I've only used it for two days but I've had audio drop-out problems and the interface is terrible.  The icons for apps take up the entire screen so you have one or two big blocks (say netflix and hulu) on your screen and you have to scroll to see the other icons.  The interface is clunky at best.  The voice control gets all messed up if you say "play star trek..." instead of "star trek..."It only allows the game controller to be added via bluetooth.  I can not add a bluetooth keyboard or headset.  This is a problem since there are lots of search fields in non-Amazon apps that you have to use the arrows to select letters.  Also entering user id's and passwords gets cumbersome and each app, of course, wants it's own login info.There's also a lack of consistency between the apps.  Different options and ways of doing things.  It really feels like it was thrown together by several departments that didn't really communicate at all.I have an existing AppleTV and it's so much more reliable, configurable, searchable than the AmazonTV.  AppleTV is not near as fast as the AmazonTV in doing anything but simply having a big processor won't compensate for not being able to do anything with it.I'm sure there are better things in this device; however, my experience in the first day of ownership was really disappointing and I am not going any further.  I'm going to return it for a refund.
author: C. Barker "Saddle Bear"

review: I don't know how many stars to give this. I just plugged it in and found that although the Fire supports HBO and Showtime. It appears my cable provider Charter doesn't support Fire. So it has to go back.I'm bummed because the rest of it looks great.

author: Gfry

review: Wife signed up for prime trial to get free shipping over holidays.  Having discovery and scifi content in the catalog was enough to keep it so bought a fire tv box since can't use our perfectly fine Apple TV (yeah another box).  First fire tv purchased, the remote was so bad could barely navigate to get connected, buttons sticking and or reading multiple presses then various lag in navigation GUI as well.  Trying to sort through interface to see instant content to stream was a joke buried under a steaming pile of crud being shoved down your throat.  We don't buy movies and certainly have no intention of buying individual tv shows.  Anyhow, via ipad finally got favorites identified as interface better in the app and could add to favorites.  Now fast forward, exchanged fire tv for another, remote much better out of the box it actually worked... well for a few hours anyways before just as bad as other...  Using Amazons ipad remote app was far better but tired of the pos hardware that came with it... second one returned and guess what, didn't come home with a third!  So disappointed, we went back to using airplay because that honestly kicked fire tvs arse up one side and down the other.  We did end up hanging on prime (wife's choice, I wouldn't have) so airplay it is.  I watch most tv on my laptop anyhow so let's get the Win8 app for it... seriously, prime isn't available in the windows app store either?  You have to be flipping kidding me I have to navigate a web browser on my surface pro or download some hobbiest programmers MCE plugin and pray it works and isn't some type of trojan?  Prime is almost as immature as fire tv, the ecosystem is a joke... a joke on me, as the consumer.
author: Jason Jozwiak
